reviewText:
Not impressed,

looks and feels like a mediocre console port, doesn't behave like a sequel (spiritual or otherwise) to the previous Sacred title(s).

While this wouldn't be entirely bad, it's almost a completely different game. If I had to compare it to something, I would compare it to what happened with Dungeon Siege 2 & 3, the latter being re-worked and again, turned into a console port-esq game.

While it's not a terrible game, I don't think it merits the price tag and it certainly doesn't follow along the open-world, Sacred 2 style of gameplay. Instead you end up with an instanced game that loses a lot of the depth and customization of it's fore-runners.

It's not a bad game per se, but I can't help but feel let down. I really enjoyed Sacred 2 and looked forward to a sequel. If anything, this feels like it should be a seperate, stand-alone game.

tl;dr It's not a bad game, but it doesn't feel worth the price tag. If you like this sort of game, you may like it, but if you expect a sequel to Sacred 2 (or the expansion), the gameplay is different, there's less depth and it's no longer open-world.

reviewText:
I came in to this game expecting more along the lines of Sacred 1 and 2. I watched the intro movie, it seemed similar as well. Stupidly enough, i did not watch any reviews before getting the game.

The two things I loved about sacred were the open world, where one could go whereever one wished, and the equipment. There's something gratifying about finding that new special weapon, or upgrading it just so.

Then there's Sacred 3.  Linear storyline. No open world. You are driven from room to room in mission" like episodes instead of picking up a bunch of quests and picking and choosing.

reviewText:
Pros:
+Fun, bit challenging gameplay
+Colorful graphics
+Good variety of heros to play with
+Co-op
Cons:
-Money is meaningless in the late game
-All of the item's (besides the health potion) are useless are you just forget that you have any.
-Story is a bit bland and packed with humor that isn't really funny, more like iritating at some points.
-Dlc content is weak. There two new mini-campaing consisting of four missions each. There your typical mission. No new enemy types in there.Then there are two heros offerd like a dlc and a weapon spirit that is just now good.
-On the begging I thought that the bosses were actually really well made and you need to use some kind of tactic to get around them. But unfortunetly after few fights you can see I HUGE amounts reskins that were made and you could clearly see that this demonic boar is nearly the same as the ice golem you fought seconds ago.
-The constant diaoulog can get very irritating.
-Mission structure is very repetetive. The missions are a copy-paste of another mission.
-Difficulty spikes
-Side-missions and Dlc campaings are making you a bit overpowered

Longevity: 10.7 hours

Verdict: 5/10

This isn't a bad game. It's just clearly not developed. As the core gameplay is fun, the missions aren't after a while, which make them a chore to go thru.But I had buckets of fun even alone. Now a very important thing I have to tackle is the game franchise. Sacreed 3 isn't the same genre like Sacred 1&2 BUT it doesn't mean that you HAVE to hate this game just for it's name. Of course I have to agree that the game had really stupid amount of Day One Dlc and the price wasn't the best but this game doesn't deserve such huge amount of hate on steam just for that. And it's completly functional. I have only encountred ONE bug. For me this game was an enjoyable game for the weekend and if you are a fan of brawlers I do recommend buying it.

reviewText: Having played Sacred 1 and 2, this seems to be almost nothing like those two games.  They got rid of most customization and loot.  It is like the developers forgot that people like getting loot.  It is the reason games like Diablo and Borderlands do so well.  The storyline seems almost non-existant and most of the time when there is story you just wish the people would shut up so that you can deal with the inevitable threat that is showing up while your character is in it's cutscene talking.  The graphics are nice I guess, but for how much space the game takes I honestly expected better.  My advice would be to a game like Guantlet.  Gameplay and graphics are similar but you feel like you get a little more reward for your effort and the game costs about half what Sacred 3 does.

reviewText:
This is only partial review from the SecTSys Gaming Group.

Sacred 3 is an arcade Hack ‘n’ Slash game for up to four players,  - so why does it cost £50 if it is only an arcade game?
Master special attacks and quickly decimate hoards of enemies, - sorry these special attacks a limited to only 4 light and 3 heavy per charactor
Equip dynamic weapon spirits to empower your journey - I am really sorry - but how is this a highlight or even a feature.

Where is the open world? what made you take all the best bits out of the game and then possed you to patch in a broken mechanic - with no loot drops, bad combat mechanics, and a whole heap of other issues ranging from Crashes - to being unable to invite friends on steam.

You should have thought about this game before releasing it and ruining the Sacred Franchise...

reviewText: I saw that there was a Sacred 3 game coming up, and I was excited. Sacred 1 and 2 are awesome games. After playing this one though, the first comparison that came to my mind was to Dungeon Siege 3. This game is to Sacred 1 and 2 what Dungeon Siege 3 was to Dungeon Siege 1 and 2.\n\nThis game is very linear with no open exploration possible. There are no towns, no npcs giving side quests. There is no loot system, and the skill system from 1 and 2 is gone. The skill/equipment system it does have has some promise, it reminds me of the skill talent system from Mass Effect 3 Multiplayer. Unfortunately, it isn't enough to save what otherwise appears to be a lackluster and short game.

reviewText:
UPDATE: You may want to search around and find out what happened to the devs of Sacred 1 & 2. Even if you don't care about those earlier titles. It's has nothing to do with the gameplay and as such I won't change my review. But Deep Silver (who the devs lost the franchise to) is now on my blacklist for being real life vilains.

I enjoy this game, had it a different title to ease minds and a 20$ price tag I'd recommend it as is.

Yes the levels are really linear but I wouldn't call them boring, they challenge you in a variety of ways that will have you adapt your gameplay. The options you get aren't that limited as many make it sounds. The cut-scenes are well-polished, the dialogues are funny, I like the different characters (heroes and vilains alike) and they are supported by a more-than-decent voice acting.

About the franchise: I don't care much. I played the 1st and 2nd titles as time wasters while waiting for game able to outshine D2 (or at least come close). You probably know that already by now (everyone seems to be mad about it), Sacred 3 is a very different game. But it has nothing to do with the fact I do not recommend it. However, if it bothers you, well, that's another reason why you should stay away from it.

To me the root of the problem is that it wasn't meant to be played on PC, it's a really poor port of what seem to be a good console game. From the settings to the controls it really doesn't fit (yet). Some examples:
- It's easy to lose sight of your cursor and on high difficulty it often means insta death. It wouldn't have been hard to design one that is easier to spot.
- Pressing space to dodge (if you still use dodge that is, you should get block) will have your character rolling toward your cursor even if you were moving in the opposite direction. It's very unintuitive. That also could easily be fixed.
- Limited options due to the initial target (console).
- Zero way to use the keyboard to chat, you'll have to use the in game voice over IP that everyone mutes so it won't be much use. Unless you playing with friends using skype, TS, ... you won't be able to say anything to your co-op" partners.

On that last note
date: I wouldn't call it a co-op game. Multiplayer? Check. PvE? Check. Cooperation? Very little. It doesn't mean it's not fun to play with others
recommended: but you do not need to cooperate.\n\nTL;DR: Different from Sacred 1 & 2. Good casual arcade time waster that can even be a bit challenging at times. Poor PC adaptation. Way too expensive for what it is."

reviewText:
Like many other reviews, take note, this game should NOT be called Sacred.

If you were expecting something similar to Sacred 1,2, Diablo, or Titan Quest then stay away from Sacred 3.

No Loot system, no open world to explore, cringe worthy dialog.

If this game was called something else, and perhaps priced cheaper then you'd more likely be getting what is advertised, but as it is, it's a complete shambles to be titles Sacred 3 and everyone should be able to get their money back.

Shame on the developers, they have tarnished the Sacred name with this abomination of a game

reviewText:
First off i cannot describe the utter sense of dissapointment i felt on august 1. The 30 gig install went smooth, i was looking forward so much to play sacred 3, a game I imagined to be much more enjoyable and with more depth than diablo 3.
When i started i was already baffled at the char selection. You simply select 1 person, no name change, no customization, NOTHING. It felt like chosing a fighter in streetfighter 2.
From then on the game went on, linear hack and slash, braindead button mashing without any thought into it.
The voice over is terrible and the attempted humor is so sad its worse than a so called hollywood *parody*.
I have stuck in there and played on, to see if any shred of the old game returns later on, sadly i have to say about halfway into the game (after a measly few hours), nothing changes, the bosses dont get any better.
Sacred 3 - Worst game i have EVER played, mostly because it should have been this other game..
If refunds were possible, this would be top of my list to get my money back on.

reviewText:
LOAD OF S.H.I.T! THIS IS NOT SACRED GAME ANY MORE.

...I'm really disappointed in this game.

A few months ago, I pre-ordered X Rebirth on steam, and received a console-recycled, bug-ridden, unplayble mess. I promised myself that I would never buy a game again without waiting for reviews.

But I was fooled again, blinded by the pre-order bonuses of Sacred 3, and the fond memories I had of S1 & S2.

S3 is pretty, but that's it. The controls are clearly made for a console. On PC, you move your character with WASD, and you have only 4 attacks/skills (2 on mouse, keys 1 and 2). You evade with space, but have no control on it's direction. Lot's of destructible elements, but you'll often have to strike 3 times before one of your swings actually hit what's right in front of you. All of that make for clumsy control of your character on PC.

Don't expect much of character personnalisation, either. There is no cosmetic or gender choices to make, and only 8 skills per class.
There's also a ever-present comedic routine, fun for the first 10 minutes, but it gets old very fast.
But the one thing I can't forgive, is that there's no loot. Sacred 3 is a Hack&Slash without loot.

Imagine Diablo 3 without items, choice of weapons, dumbed down controls and with only a handful of skills. Would you like to play it?

TL,DR: Never, ever buy a game right when it's release, and Sacred 3 is a fraud for using the Sacred licence.

reviewText:
As I started the game, i was amazed by the brilliant graphics and the three teasers in the menu and couldnt wait to play.
Just to find myself disappointed merely seconds later by just EVERYTHING: The storytelling is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t and the narator sounds boring and even annoying by desperately trying to be funny. The great atmosphere set up by the images is ruined by too flashy texts and the queaky teenage voice of Aria makes you wanna strangle her, why is she even there?
Can't I explore the world on my own, without an annoying girl wathing my every step?
The grave setting of great pictures is totally drawn into ridiculousness, and the streetfighter-like ingame display completely prevents you from sinking into this world.
The RPG part is not even there, I mean why would you choose from 5 protagonists when after all you have no chance to evolve your own character ingame? There is NO point in leveling up, you dont get to pick any new skill and there is NO way to equip your character.
Not to mention that the combat system can be quite annoying for those who played Hack&Slash before.
So please, do not buy this game just because you liked Sacred&Sacred2 (or other H&Ss)

reviewText:
Sacred 3 is a very good game. It's a beat-em-up brawler similar to Gauntlet just better, although that's probably a matter of taste. The only thing this game is not is Sacred.

I am not aware of any other game on Steam that received as many negative ratings as Sacred 3 has. The reason for this are unfulfilled expectations. That's because Sacred 3 has nothing to do with Sacred 1 or Sacred 2. The game is neither an open-world game nor a role-playing game and the only thing Sacred 1 and Sacred 2 share with Sacred 3 is the name. If you can accept that and you like hack and slay games Sacred 3 is a very enjoyable game.

Pros:

- nice graphics, beautiful landscapes
- character specific weapons, armor, special attacks
- weapon upgrades
- armor upgrades
- special attacks (upgradeable)
- 15 diversified levels in the main game
- good DLCs
- good music
- co-op
- multi-player, lobbies are currently full (October 2015)
- co-op in combination with multi-player (two co-op, two mp)
- you only collect gold (which keeps you from searching for scrolls and any other hidden stuff)
- very easy to join games
- you can join or leave games at any time
- four difficulty levels (last difficulty is accessible after first play-through)

Cons:

- it's not Sacred
- leveling up can get tiresome. Once you reached level 30 it takes a lot of time and fighting to collect the necessary experience points to level up further.

There are dissent opinions about the dialogs in the game. Please take into considerations that the game supports different languages with different translations and speakers.
During your journey you are accompanied by Aria, a telepathic, informing you about upcoming events, enemies dangers, areas, etc. She keeps talking all the time and at least in German her voice acting is great. Then you can select a god that inhabits your weapon, providing some special abilities. The selected god keeps talking too. The gods talking strongly reflect their diverse personalities and they tend to exaggerate.
Dialogs are often childish with a strong use of youth slang. They tend to not take the game seriously and are very grotesque. It's the grotesqueness that makes the dialogs funny again, provided you have the right sense of humor.
I like them, especially Aria is great in German.

reviewText:
Sacred 3
This is a fun hack and slash, action, rpg type game. So far what I have played of the game is fun, and I am really enjoying it. The bosses are tough, but once you learn a good strategy they are not so bad. After you complete the first big boss you can spend your gold and upgrade your weapons and abilitys, but so far during a mission I have not been able to spend my gold only at the beginning of a mission, I have found that I can.

The game is not perfect and is very playable, and it plays great with the Xbox controller with no issues that I have found so far. All I can really say about this game, is if you enjoy hack and slash type games similiar to Torchlight, then you should enjoy this game as well.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=536435965

I dont understand why there is so many negative reviews, because I dont have an issue with this game at all.

Price wise at 75% off sale price at the moment its a steal, but I do recomend getting the  Sacred 3 GOLD edition" as you will get all the dlc's included

reviewText:
Very Disappointed. Why use the name of a well-loved game and then make a whole new game? When I pre-purchase this game I did so in good faith, and what did you do?  You stamp “Sucker” on my forehead as the ACH money transfer cleared. I will not patronize this kind of business practices. I would like my money back!

A message to long term Sacred fans: do not purchase this game in its present form. It is not Sacred in any way, shape or form! If you want a new console game with the theme of Sacred then this is for you. However if you are looking for the rich, complex, open world game Sacred has always been in past editions, this is NOT it!

To the developers: please change the name of this game to something that does not mislead customers, or make an actual Sacred game. Thinking outside the box is one thing, but this is well…

reviewText: You ever purchased a game and within the first five minutes of playing, thought oh, god, what have I done?  Have I ever wasted my money on a worse game?  Probably, yes, but at the moment, nothing's coming to mind.  It's got some vaguely redeemable features but it's lost in the pure crap that is the plot and the dialogue and the gameplay just simply isn't good enough when nobody in the game will shut up (if you thought the things the characters in Sacred 2 had to say were dumb, wait until you meet the telepathic idiot who directs your every move in this one... or hell, just sit through the first video with all the characters in it) and everything that comes out of their mouths convinces me that this game was written by a teenager who thinks he's the wittiest thing ever because none of his small circle of friends has the heart to tell him he's annoying as ♥♥♥♥.  It's like this game took everything that was even slightly redeemable about Sacred 2 and tossed it out the window, then ramped up the content on everything that wasn't.

reviewText:
Got this game (gold edition) for a few bucks in a humble bundle. And it was well worth it!

This game does NOT deserve as much negative cricism as it has been getting. So long as you dont look at it as a sacred game. This game is very similar to Gauntlet and plays just the same. A hack and slash light RPG.

Pro's:
-Beautiful level design
-Many items and skills to equip and improve upon to make your character unique
-Smooth multiplayer (very rarely has hiccups)
-Some tough boss fights (A lot of dark soulsy roll and hit)
-Story is fun even in single player, however multiplayer has its own charm and is encouraged
-Quite a few playable classes each with their own skills
-Fun traps to avoid and watch friends blow up from

Cons:
-Too many health drops (this could be solved by reducing HP drops frequency or effectiveness with high difficulty)
-Some average enemies at times (while fun and overwhelming) can seem heavy on the ground" with too little health
-Would love to see one more difficulty setting
date: ex. "insane mode" or something of the sort\n-not so much a con
recommended: as it is more rather just goofy
hoursPlayed: but the playful tone of the script while also trying to tell a somewhat serious story\n\nOverall this game is reccommended to Gauntlet fans and those that want to slaughter hordes of enemies with their friends as they have in all arcade style hack and slashes."

reviewText:
Do you think is a good idea to get Sacred 3, after playing Sacred and Sacred 2? well, that's not a good idea, and I'll explain why:
Do you remember this open world where you can walk wherever you want and take main and side missions? forget about it. Every stage (yes, there are stages, not missions) are just walking a corridor fighting some foes, then run a little bit for another corridor where stones fall from sky, then some more foes and then a final boss. That's it. Every stage. There are some where the stone falling is skipped and you fight some foes and then the final boss, though.
Lets talk about customization:
You get a weapon and you can upgrade it. Forget to get loot, besides some gold and heal. You have two potions that you can use when you die and thats it. Then, when you finish a stage, you can upgrade" your weapon. But only a little bit because you dont have enough level to buy next.
And the worst part is that every two steps you do

reviewText:
I usualy do not write reviews. But I just felt obligated to write a few words about this game.

Sacred 1+2 Was both fun and good games. Comparable to titles like e.g. Diablo and the free to play game Path of exile. Not as great, but good fun and worth playing.
Well... I can't say the same about this game, exept, Sacred 3 it is not. I can not with good conscience recommend this game to anyone. And if you should buy it, prepare to be disappointed. Pure Hack'n'Slash, no open world, and no loot what so ever. In other words, they have taken the things that makes these games fun to play, and left it with something that feels hollow and boring.
Save your money for something else guys.

Now if you will have me excused. Im going to find a hammer, so I can hit myself on my head, for buying this game without reading a review first... Hmm maybe I'll get lucky and drop some loot.

reviewText: I would absolutely advise against this game, especially if you've played EITHER of the first two. This game is not Sacred. It just isn't. It's some crap hack'n'slash game that doesn't look, feel or play like any of the Sacred games. It's not the same style, it doesn't even feel like it's the same world. The game isn't just different, it's also bad. The combat is literally spamming a button until a big enemy spawns, then using an ability, then returning to the same routine. Bosses are scaled to seem incredibly difficult but they also all have their own built in routines, stand back and dodge everything the boss throws at you for the first run of the fight and then you know exactly how to fight him, without even being close to being hit. I was excited about Sacred 3 as soon as I heard it was coming and now that it's out it has no similarities with the original. I wouldn't be so annoyed if they had just called it something other than Sacred, as it stands this does not fit into the trilogy" if you even want to acknlowledge this as being part of the Sacred series."

reviewText:
NOTE: This game specifically is the reason I do NOT pre-order games anymore.

Yes, I have not spent much time on this game, but cannot stomach playing a game that is not an RPG as I had believed going by the trend of the first two Sacred games. I did finally almost reach an hour...

If you enjoyed Sacred 1 & 2 and expect the same type of game play from this game, do NOT buy this game.

If you enjoy arcade hack and slash and clicking the button on your mouse or control thousands of times over and over killing the same lookalike enemies. Then you might enjoy this game.

This game has no depth, it is a very shallow game. The voice overs and jokes are atrocious in the least. The jokes are not funny, but just ignorant.

The price on this game WILL drop, wait till then to try it. With the backlash this game has recieved over butchering the series, it will have to drop it's prices to get any buyers.

reviewText:
It's not Sacred 1 or 2. But an arcade Hack and slash like they always stated that it was. If you liked the previous games, don't get this.

Stages are linnear with some hidden treasure and tons of enemies to kill. Choose one of 5(6) characters to fight the enemies, each chracter can assign two skills besides the light and heavy attacks. You can also choose between skills and different weapons. Earn money to upgrade skills and weapons to improve your fighter in differernt ways. You also have to make some gamechanging choices on whether you want to use Block or Dodge roll.

The writing and script is rather terrible though, it makes Trine 2 seem serious.

Strange relations: Dungeon siege 3, combat is pretty simmilar with limited skills. Although DS is a lot more open and has loot. Drakengard 3 with the pretty similar gameplay of simplistic battle system and linear stages ended with bosses. Heavenly Sword, with the combat system where you are expected to break guards and fight different kinds of enemies in different ways. Also, the villains kinda remind of each other. Old Action hack and slashes like Excalibur or any Warriors game. Devil May Cry because - nah just kidding, this has nothing on Devil may cry.


Would be better if this wasn't Sacred 3 but rather Sacred Capitol 2 or something.
PS: If you are looking for a coop hack and slash to enjoy then I would suggest Forced. Kinda simmilar but puzzles to solve and most stages are arenas rather than pathways.

reviewText:
I don't get why this game gets all the hate. I mean, sure, I only picked up the Gold Edition once it was 75% off. In fact, this is actually a review of Sacred 3 Gold at the total price of $7.50 USD. Ok? Ok.

So, Sacred 3 Gold is:
+ a fun, if somewhat repetitive hack'n'slash.
+ Has a good variety to the levels.
+ Gives you access to 6 unique warriors.
+ Has a stream-lined, but flexible RPG system that allows you to easily change your specs between missions.
+ Weapon Spirits add a bit of extra variety.

There are things that are a bit hit-and-miss, though:
= Like the humour. Absurd, low-brow, and extremely silly. You'll get a few chuckles, sure, but mostly you'll be shaking your head. (I play with the orc and he's actually pretty hilarious)
= The main story levels are pre-set in their level requirements, which you will surpass very quickly. That is to say, the game will get progressively easier as you go. Don't worry, boss fights are still tough and the DLC missions adjust difficulty according to your level.
= The story? Oh yeah, I forgot. ... I think you have to save the world or something?

There is only, really, one issue I have with the game:
- You aim your dodge with the mouse. Whoever though that was a good idea needs to have some sense knocked into them.

reviewText: Honestly, I don't get why the game gets so much hate. Yeah, it's not Sacred as we know it. Yeah, it's fairly simple in design. But it's fun, very pleasant to look at, the commentary from Aria and Ghosts are often quite funny, the characters are diverse enough to not be bored to hell, from mallets to bow, to scythes there's something for everyone. It's a great time-waster in my opinion, a solid product with no pretence of being something more than a good ol' fanshioned fun pad-smasher.\nAll I'm saying is, if this game had a different title, people would approach it very differently. It's a terrible Sacred game, but it's pretty darned decent as its own thing. Nothing newsworthy, of course, but a solid product nonetheless.

reviewText:
I would go to my Cousin's house and take my laptop so i can play Sacred 3 on xbox and he plays Witcher 2 on my laptop,and we had so much fun playing and staying awake all night for Sacred 3 coop on xbox,all this happened on the summer vacation June 2015 so today 25th of November 2015 i decided to get this game on pc,and here's my review of this pc version of the game.

POSITIVES
*Nostalgia hit me so hard in the head when i played this game and i remembered them good ol' days.

*Decent enviroment design.

*I liked the classic arcade feel of the game overall.

*Decent looking skill animations.

NEGATIVES
-The Audio is so ♥♥♥♥ing bad that it broke my headset,internally ofcourse.

- It clearly says FULL CONTROLLER SUPPORT on the store page,but when i plugged my controller it didn't work at all and no the problem isn't my controller because its fully functional on other games.

-Same case with the controller,Mouse doesn't work sometimes.

- I did mention that the skill animations are decently looking on the pros section but the actual combat itself is all button mashing and gets repetitive really ♥♥♥♥ing quickly

- You can't play on Fullscreen,it just doesn't work even if you go to settings and enable fullscreen and highest resolution
it's still in windowed mode.

* The voice acting is so bad and the charecters try so hard to be funny and they're not. not at all

Refunded
and im not going to talk about the sacred 2 genre migration,im not going to ♥♥♥♥ing do it.

The combat (if you can call it that) consists of mashing the left mouse button with the occasional 1 or 2 key added for a special move which are kinda useless so it will mostly be mashing left click until an enemy with a shield comes then you press right click to break their guard and stun them for a second so you can, yep you guessed it spam the left mouse button.

reviewText:
There are no spoilers in this review.

To begin,
-This game is a completely different genre from it's predecessors.
-The mechanics are more suited for handheld console play (think PSP/ 3DS/ mobile app). I would even go so far to say that this PC port felt more like an afterthought.

Game complexity: I am not against grinding as a game mechanic, because there can be good grinding games where you're constantly on your toes, and then there's bad ones. Sacred 3 falls under the latter - I fell asleep while clearing mobs because there's virtually no challenge - press button, monster dies. HP/Mana management? Choosing the right equipment for the right fights? Fret not, you are released from that burden in this game. </s>

Replayability: The only reason to try out other characters is to see their skills. You can get the same experience from watching a YouTube video of the characters, then you're back to facing the same levels all over again.

I wrote this review having owned a PSP myself, and played hack-and-slash games such as Dynasty Warriors, DMC3, God of War, Ryse, and many others. Avoid this game at all costs - even if it was free, your time could be spent on other games instead.

reviewText:
A complete misuse of the Sacred intellectual property.

This game could have stood a chance if it didn't carry the Sacred name, ultimately misleading hordes of Sacred fans. If it was called Sacred Citadel 2" or "Citadel: A Sacred Tale" people would likely have been more forgiving.

Naming and false-advertising aside
date: the game in and of itself is mediocre. If you're looking for an isometric co-op action game you've get several better alternatives."

reviewText: I enjoyed Sacred 2, which was the first game of this series I played, so I was curious about this game, having picked it up recently in a bundle package.  I finally installed it hoping that it might have some sort of semblance to the game that I had played a number of years ago... I suppose that idea was dashed within moments of starting the game.  Instead of a semi-open world it has been changed into a series of select a location, fight through the enemy lines, rinse and repeat.  There is no replayability as you just do the same thing over and over and over again through the course of the game, finish an area, get an award screen and maybe a level up, start the next scene, get an uninspiring introduction voice over.  There is no longer a loot system, just pick up gold that you use to unlock new inventory items that are gained through level unlock... if the boss is too hard, just go back a section and grind it a few times...  I slogged through ten levels of character development and don't ever plan on looking at this again as there are much better wastes of my time.

reviewText:
Why so much rage? Disappointed much?

When getting this during a sale, and approaching it without overblown expectations, this is quite a decent game - not great, but not as bad as some reviews indicate it to be.

If you like fast-paced button smashers/monster bashers, and look at a few hours of simple, relaxing gameplay, this is an OK game in the vein of Gauntlet and similar (Dungeon Siege without loot), with some decent graphics. Don't expect much RPG content, though.

Most boss fights are doable (some quite hard, though - especially the Dark Seraphim), and tbh I found the worst part (except for the Dark Seraphim) to a map with the spike traps around Level 20, where you start pretty far back when you die.

Replayability, though, is so/so at best.

Worst game ever, as some reviewers have stated? Not by a long long distance - there are literally hundreds of games worse than this.

reviewText:
Don't even consider buying this crap, there are many better games in it's more action oriented hack'n'slash genre with the RPG elements kept to minimum.

I really enjoyed Sacred 1, mildly liked Sacred 2, but this... They just made a game and needed to brand it something so it would sell, so they marketed it as the third main entry in Sacred franchise. They slapped on a generic story butchering all the stuff set up in previous games. I've seen fanfiction written better than this. They probably realized it's ♥♥♥♥ so they added 4th wall breaking self-deprecating humor to everything characters say, probably to shield it from criticism about how bad it is. It didn't work, and now we have a product with a ♥♥♥♥ story that just tells you how ♥♥♥♥ it is. Amazing.

This is a disgrace to the series, as Arcania was to the Gothic franchise.

reviewText:
The in-depth custumization and character development, as well as massive world with many side quests in Sacred 2, which we had hoped from Sacred 3... dissappointment is really what it it. If you are looking for a massive open game like Sacred 2, this isn't it. This is litterally nothing like Sacred 2, except the fact that you only get to pick a few characters and no real customization.

They took a whole new approach, and tried to tap into the more action combat gameplay. Although this game does that quite well, it is just like many other games of its kind, but less imaginative. Graphics are pretty decent and action combat is alright.

Sacred 2 voice overs were actually pretty decent, but Sacred 3's is absolute terrible. They tried to half heartedly make the game funny, which turned into pathetic. The best voice over would be the first battle spirit you come across. He is quick witted, funny, and enjoyable to listen to. Problem was that the game made very little indication as to who was actually talking. Pretty much I had no idea it wasn't the character I was playing as talking for a bit.

Gameplay is average at best, boring as heck at worst. Every single mission basically plays out the same. Waves of bad guys with varying abilities you HAVE to use to even kill them. Bosses with all the same basic skills, then repeat. Pretty simple really, if they have a shield above their head, you have to knock it away. Otherwise you just keep moving and killing. Like Dynasty Warriors, but not as cool.

The absolute worst part of the game, is the variety. Every single hero plays exactly the same. Sure you can pick two skills, but most of the skills are about the same. Some are a complete waste to even pick, which lowers the variety even more. You can pick your weapon, but they are very similar so it won't even matter much.

For the price tag, I would say this game is totally not worth it. There are many MANY games out there that have more depth to them for a fifth the price. I would only get this game if it is on super sale for 75% off or more.

reviewText: Asides from the fact that it is not the open-world I am used to concerning Sacred games, this is a good game in its own way. reviewText: I get it that the die hard fans of the first two games are ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off that this is so different, but seriously this game is fun.  The RPG elements are tuned down, but frankly sometimes you dont actually care to spend hours tweaking attributes and juggling gear scores...   Sometimes you just want to dive in and murder the crap out of hordes of monsters!!   This game is very enjoyable, but more Golden Axe than Diablo...  (Or Sacred 1/2)  and that's not a bad thing.  It DOES however feel like it started as one game, and ended up as another in some ways.  The voice acting isnt bad, but the writing seems out of place?  There are a lot of really bad jokes and some dumb one liners in there, but in a way it still comes off as charming, but seems incongruous with the presentation of the rest of the game.  That said, maybe the corn is better than having the game take itself too seriously and come off as unintentionally hokey?  Anyhow, it's a satisfying romp with lots of flying bodies and smashed set pieces, and that's pretty damn fun in of itself.

reviewText:
I havent got a Huge amount of game time under my belt but in my hour or two (felt like ages) of playing all i can say is this.

Gameplay is good, does justice (not spectacular) and is easy to get a feel for and get into which is nomally an issue with games like this. Camera panning, movement etc is fine and it works ok.

Basic story... like reaaaal basic as in the kind of story you've seen on most other RPG's its not a terrible story but it feels quite droll.

Now comes the fun part the voice acting and dialogue... this was something different.
Imagine going to a comedy show and the act starts: ok looks good
date: bit of humour (not normal in most fantasy RPG's) something different. Now imagine 5 minutes in the humour makes you cringe and if it was a live performance all you want to do is tell the comedian to sit down or just leave. Thats the dialogue and voice acting... and the sad part is it gets on you and really detracts from the rest of the game wherein you feel like you're getting the hang of a pretty ok game
recommended: something nice to pass the time with and then you get bombarded with humour that is trying so hard to be funny but simply isn't and in all honesty if the game character and story was a bit more serious (including narration
hoursPlayed:
don't even get me started  great voice actor but the narration seemed offish) the game would and could have been a far more enjoyable experience.

With this said the game isn't absolutely unplayable and is quite pretty in a cartoony fashion but the story and voice acting really does it in.

5.7/10"

reviewText:
By now everyone should know that this is not truly the successor to Sacred 1 and 2, despite the name. So if that is what you are looking for, move on.

If you ignore the history and just evaluate the game itself, it is a solid Hack'n'Slash. It is more an advanced version of Gauntlet than a dumbed down ARPG (the point of view all the disappointed S2 fans take).

If you want an ARPG, this is not the game for you, limited skill selection and no loot make this a no-go. If you want more of a brawler, go for it, combat is good enough imo, areas are nice but very linear. You collect some money per mission and can upgrade skills with it.

Notice that the controls are better for a controller, so if you use keyboard and mouse and do not like WASD movement, do not get the game either (WASD works, controller is better).

You also will have to overlook the stupid attempt at humor this game has in really all narration and that you unfortunately cannot turn off.

If you can look past that, want a Hack'n'Slash, not an ARPG, and are ok with WASD (or better yet with using a controller), it is a solid game. Not outstanding, but also not deserving all the bad ratings from the disappointed S2 fans that are predominantly upset about this not being a true successor.

reviewText: This is an uncomplicated, easy to pick up, mission based isometric brawler with smooth drop-in co-op (both offline and online, up to 4 players). The main campaign can be played entirely in co-op mode, which is always a big plus. You choose between four different classes, which all feel appropriately different to play. More classes can be bought as DLC. This is not an open world game, you will be running down narrow corridors most of the time, but that kinda comes with the genre. There is no loot to speak of (only gold + health and mana orbs), instead you unlock new items and skills by leveling up or beating bosses. You can upgrade your stuff by paying gold. Bosses are varied (one can be a troll, another a ship, etc) and you need to employ different skills for each fight. XBox360 controller is recommended.\n\nAll in all I must say I have enjoyed my time with this game so far, and would recommend it to anyone who is looking for something fun to play with their friends.

reviewText: A beautifully detailed, I liked the fluid gameplay and the special effects. Levels are designed like arenas, defeat all enemies and you can move on. There is no inventory and constant looting. This makes the experience more arcade-like, and ultimately a different experience but still very interesting. Team up with three like-minded friends for a bunch of monster-smashing, and Sacred 3 has plenty to offer. For all intents and purposes, Sacred 3 is a beat ‘em up that can be very fun. Game is so very different from previous installments in this series, this game dedicated to consoles and couch gaming". But if you put aside your prejudice
date: you could enjoy Sacred 3 - it's a pretty good action game with a epic fantasy setting."

reviewText:
Things first, I haven't played any of the prequels. That said, I find the hack and slash quite entertainment. There is just a small array of skills you can use and just two you can equip. That's quite odd. Though, I the actual combat isn't really bad. You have a set of variety in enemies and how you take them out. You need to bash them for shields or take out timers before you melee them. Using a bit of environment objects as you playground .. yeah. Nice.. Just don't expect it to be a top A Game.

They characters are stereotypes. You'll quickly learn what type everyone is and expect them to say things, they will. There is a story, but it's just to keep you fighting. No extreme demons from hell raising to overwhelm the planet.. there is an invasion, mwah. >.< I also don't really give to much about the humor level. Still considering the medium story and cheap characters, it actually is fitting.

Characters .. story, not so much. Battle system is quite entertaining. ( again, I haven't played the prequels! I review this game as it is, standalone ). 29.99 ... far too much. Can't recommend it for that price. 14.99 , fine, that's doable. Whenever it gets around the 9.99.. go for it.

reviewText:
The “overwhelmingly negative” reviews are a prime example of the abuse of the steam review system. This is not, by any means within itself, a bad game. Look at the number of reviews, around 2200+, and just know that that is how many fans worldwide there are of Sacred 1 and 2 lol. So of course when this game comes out and is not like the other games but in the fans terms is a “dumbed down button masher” of course every fan of Sacred 2 will hate it because it isn't like Sacred 2 which is a Diablo-esque type. What I love most about this game, besides that it ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off all of the idiot fans, is that they made it into a type of game that is always fun, a isometric arcade beat 'em up style game. I could've cared less if it was another Diablo style game because Diablo 3 is just fine and I hear the expansion is pretty good too which I will buy eventually. My 2 hour playtime of Sacred 2 included being killed in three hits by the first two guys that my mage came across, then respawning and using a big summon demon spell that killed them then turned around and KILLED ME, LOL, then I made a warrior and ran around for another hour or two bored while waiting for steam to come back online so I could play L4D2 with some friends. So yea, we didn't need another newer version of Sacred 2.

I am glad that it isn't a continuation of Sacred 2 because I hate that game. It has a crappy interface, is old as dirt so it is not as accessible as Diablo 3 in terms of keybinds, skill use, and being streamlined to include all of the hundreds of little things that make Diablo 3 so worry free. Honestly though I do understand why the fans are upset because this game is such a huge change over the last ones. But like I said, forgetting about those games and judging it by itself, it is actually really fun, especially in co-op. I was just playing online and someone joined my game and we were having a lot of fun, even though he was a complete ret-rd and wouldn't vote on the next map so I had to sit in the lobby with him and wait a full minute before each match lols.

It truly is a well made game in terms of production value, definitely feels like a AAA button masher. But you can't just mash buttons you have to dodge and be smart so it isn't a mindless action fighting game. This game is by far best experienced with a xbox 360 controller so have one. It has some boss fights that actually take some skill to beat and some monsters that can kill you if you aren't careful. The humor sucks it is just dumb but everything else is well done and the game runs perfectly smooth on high. Great sounds and music, good voice acting even if it is too silly much of the time, the controls are tight, the graphics are awesome, the effects are awesome, the enemies are cool, the bosses are really fun, the skills are few but interesting, you have a arsenal of potions to use, and you can swap/upgrade weapons, armor, and skills. The only negatives I can say are that I am not a fan of button mashers unless they are really fun which this is, because my idea of fun is not a sore hand all day so I limit my time per day with mashers, and it won't save my resolution on relaunch but whatever, I just take a second and reset it to my native res when I start the game.

8/10 I got this for $10 and it is definitely worth that much at the very least.
8/10 Malakhim character dlc I bought and play as. I got it on sale for like $1.30 and it is worth it for a fun character.

reviewText:
This game got many negative reviews, which I find rather unfair. Sacred 3 is not Sacred or Sacred 2. It's not an RPG with an open world where you can run around and complete quests. This is what many people expected and why so many are disappointed. Sacred 3 is an extremely linear Hack'n Slash game with lots of action and (in my opinion) nice graphics. It takes place in Ancaria. That's pretty much all it has in common with its predecessors.

Nevertheless, it is a decent game. The visuals are well done, controls are intuitive (if you play with a controller) and accurate. You constantly need various buttons which are much easier to reach on a controller than a keyboard. Further, the game has a online as well as a local co-op mode. Playing with others is much more fun and something I would definitely recommend to do.

The only thing I found annoying after a while are the comments of your companions. I guess, the developers aimed at being funny. They are not. I prefer a more serious tone in the dialogues while I'm saving the world. It's not the right time to hear about wannabe romantic approaches of whatever kind of ghost I'm carrying around with me.

TL, DR: This is a good game with some minor flaws. It missed the high expectations from its loyal fans and got many undeserved bad reviews for it.
voteText: 10 of 50 people (20%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The first two Sacred games were ARPG Diablo clones; in a countless list of those going towards the early 2000's Sacred was one of the best alternatives for those that already destroyed Diablo. Sacred 2 more recently took a page from other ARPGs, but remained a stat-based action roleplaying game, just like Diablo.

Sacred Citidel would have been right at home on Kongregate or at an Arcade - it was a mediocre Castle-Crashers style beat'em'up side-scrolling RPG.

SACRED 3 hads a lot of people frothing at the mouth about how it was not true to its own roots, and it's being accused universally of being a bad game, it is not!

People are reviewing what they expected, rather than what the game is. Sacred 3 is a mixture of Sacred 1/2 and Sacred Citadel, that does not try to be an alternative to Diablo 3 (Torchlight 2 is better). In fact, what it is, is a Really Decent classic hack'n'slash adventure game. There isn't much of a loot system, there are no real stats, you sort of have levels, it's not really an RPG. It is better at being what I expected from the Gauntlet reboot (Coming later in August 2014) than what Gauntlet 2014 looks to be.

Fans of Diablo? Stay away. Missing the smashfest days of Dark Legacy? Come get some. Bring a friend and a controller.

reviewText:
This is NOT like Sacred 1 and 2. If you are expecting that coming into buying this game do not bother. If you like hack and slash games that are similar to Gauntlet with a little bit more polish and some rpg elements (skill / weapon leveling etc.) this game is for you.

Most people assumed that this was going to be Sacred 1/2, Diablo 1/2/3 rehash #9000 but it is not. It is hack and slash game straight up. You kill monsters, get gold, level up characters, skills and all the normal stuff. There is no loot and to me it is a good thing. There are already too many games making monsters / chests drop tons of worthless loot. I would rather have this, get fun skills for the different characters and go blow up tons of monsters.

Go watch some un-biased videos and reviews to make an ultimate decision on this game. Do not just pass it up because its the Sacred name rebranded with a 3 and not like the first two. People who loved the first 2 games need to take their nostalgia goggles off and look at this game for what it is....a fun hack and slash where you just collect gold and kill tons of monsters.

reviewText: If your intent with this game is a big, open, exciting world full of lore and loot, you will be sadly dissappointed. Though, discounting this game simply because of experiences with with the prior titles would cause you to miss out on a world of fun. While it lacks the deep story and customization of Sacred and Sacred 2, the new combat system is a blast to use. The story, so far anyway, is lackluster and disinteresting, but that's not what this game is about.\nFor those of you who have gotten this far, you'll like this game if you're a fan of games like Dynasty Warriors as, ironically, that's what this game feels like. In my opinion, if Sacred made a baby with the Warriors games, this is what I'd expect it to look like. Given that, I'm not surprised by the lack of story or deep customization because the intense combat is the focus. In the future, I personally hope that this combat system is kept and the old system of loot and quests brought back. I really believe that this is a step forward for the combat of the ARP genre.\nIf you can just look past the Sacred title and the history of the series, I think most will enjoy this game. Worst comes to worst, wait for a sale, but I do not suggest those interested in the ARP genre should pass it up.

reviewText: This is a classic hack 'n' slash game with advanced animation, graphics and effects. It is fairly simple in its storyline and plot, but with strong history behind the Sacred world, characters and locations. As far as the game itself is concerned; it is a lot of fun experiencing the comically interluded levels and enhancing one's character to progress, until one tries to complete the main missions on 'Deity' difficulty level, which is a great challenge. I have had a lot of fun playing it and would recommend it to anyone who likes Diablo style games, although it is more science fiction than archaic lore. A good game to play until the true fight begins on the hardest difficulty when it becomes a real key-tapping festival. Despite the 'franticity' as one gets towards level 50 (Max.) in trying to overcome the baddies and complete the storyline missions, it is well worth a crack and maybe you will overcome the challenge. (Good Luck!:)

reviewText:
Let's get this out of the way - this game is nothing like Sacred 1/2. Good, there are enough point & click ARPGs out there, and the previous Sacreds weren't all that, anyway.

The system req's should also definitely include controller(s) and a buddy. This game is made for couch co-op; there are a number of game mechanics that don't even function when playing solo.

Onto the gameplay: I found this an absolute blast. The different characters give a satisfyingly different game experience - there's the slow, hard-hitting tank, the archer / crowd-controller, and the fast-but-squishy skirmisher who excells at taking out high-value targets. Then a quite powerful hybrid who can do a bit of everything, and the pre-order bonus char, who seems a bit OP at the start but falls in line after a few levels and most resembles the skirmish character.

Combat is the main focus of this game; there's a normal melee attack that can be chained into a combo, a disabling bash that deals little damage but is absolutely crucial against certain enemies, and two 'combat arts' that require energy, which is regenerated by your regular attacks (the main similarity to previous Sacred games). Then there's a defensive move and a co-op-only battle prayer. I find it fast and fun, but I imagine it would be hell with a keyboard/mouse set-up. It is definitely not just a button masher, there are plenty of situations where chosing the wrong sort of attack spells certain doom, or at least a facefull of sword.

The game plays through individual missions, in between which you are returned to a 'lobby'. No open-world exploration. You can replay missions as often as you like, which lets you fine-tune the difficulty a bit by levelling up in easier areas if you're finding a particular mission too tough. Some of them are quite tough, you cannot simply face-roll everything in this game.

Levelling and looting is 'streamlined' by buying upgrades for gold, which is disappointing if that's not what you're after, but you still get to make meaningful choices in character builds. For example, some weapons emphasize attack area, some damage, and some special effects like knockdown or lifedrain. At some point, you will have to decide if you prefer to defend by blocking or dodging. You can experiment with everything, as the most recent upgrade in each skill line is a free buy-back, but you will not likely be able to afford to just max everything. You get to pick a new load-out before each mission.

All gear and abilities level up with your char, which means armour and weapons look progressively more bad-♥♥♥, but this is mostly cosmetic.

The other major customisation is the choice of 'weapon-spirit': these come with a more or less powerful bonus, and a corresponding flaw; for example, the vampire lets your melee attacks drain life, but reduces your health recovery from health drops. They also frequently pipe up during the game...

So, to the superficials: Graphics are uniformly gorgeous for this kind of game, with lots of detail even in the non-gaming areas. The sound-track is also suitably epic. The (English) voice-acting is excellent, and there is an awful lot of it, but what the voices have to say is... not for everyone. There's a lot of goofy, inoffensive humour, like what we'd get at the gaming table after a few beers. Some of it falls flat, some of it makes me smile (I love the drunk vampire weapon spirit). The use of accents, on the other hand, just comes off as a bit racist - not acceptable and so unnecessary.

It's not a perfect game, and better suited to an hour or so of fun hack-and-slash than to day-long immersive play, but it definitely does not deserve the hate flung at it... If you liked Champions of Norrath, Untold Legends or even the fighty bits of Kindoms of Amalur, this might push your buttons; and though this is not a ringing endorsement, it is miles better than Dungeon Siege 3

reviewText:
I've played the game for about 10 hours.  and I have to say that for what the game is... it's an enjoyable distraction for awhile.  there is definitly a lot of variation in the levels that you will come across in the game.  Also I would say that the character's abilities are different enough that you would want to try each of them to see what best fits your play style.

As for the name of the game Sacred 3, many people are getting stuck on this.  Yes I've played and have beaten both Sacred 1 and 2.  aid if you are expecting to find a game like that,  then unfortunatly you will be sadly disappointed.  and like many have said, perhaps giving this game another name would have most likely been a better option.  About the only thing that this game holds true to the sacred name is some of the characters and of course the setting of the game itself.

Pros for the game:
- Good graphics
- Drop in/drop out multiplayer.
- the player level advancement is well paced as you move through the levels
- varied boss and monster mechanics
- Unique enough playable characters that you would want to try all of them

Cons for the game:
- It's sacred in name and name only this is for the most part a top down hack 'n slash
- Character development is extremely limited you can only unlock/upgrade skills by reaching certain levels
- Finding upgrades is linked to specific levels in the game
- Game really isn't mouse/keyboard friendly, was definitly designed with consoles in mind

Over all.  the game is a nice nice distraction for awhile and also a good addition to the Sacred Universe of games but has been preveriously stated, this game really doesn't desver the title of Sacred 3 and in face this type of game could possibly spawn it's own series within the sacred universe and would have honestly been a better idea.

reviewText: Sacred always felt like the handicapped brother of Diablo. So instead of embarassing us yet again with another poor ARPG, Keen Games ditched the whole idea of the original Sacreds and turned Sacred 3 into an action game with light RPG elements. The basic gameplay is all about movement, controlling space on screen and mashing buttons to slaugter hundreds of enemies - RPG elements mostly consist of gaining XP/leveling up and being able to unlock and upgrade new skills.\n\nOne of the more interesting features are the spirits" - these give a reasonably big advantage (life steal) but not without cost (normal health pick-ups only worth 50% HP). Some of these benefit solo-players

reviewText:
It's no sacred 2 sequel, but after playing gauntlet, it definatly feels like a guantlet inspired game. Played with that mindset its more enjoyable than expecting sacred rpg equipment leveling and open world. so its a alternative more fleshed out guantlet.. and as that, its quite good! It's just not good as a sacred 2 follow up :(

For the price though, its not that much, and sadly not even any visible progression in technical features. if anything theyre heavily dumbed down in all aspects, from graphics, to speech, to lack of open world. you would think with such restricted maps, you could have better graphics than sacred 2 did with open world.. and with so many years of technology between.

So i thumbs the game up with a grain of salt so far. it is okay to play.. but it it tedious, but. its possibly better than gauntlet at being gauntlet.. co-op hacking through waves of challenges. but if you want an rpg. get sacred 2.. or torchlight 2

reviewText:
Yeah, it's not Sacred 2 open world style, with classic quests like escorting a little girl home. You know, when I'm playing as an Undead, evil-aligned shadow warrior devoted to demonic worship.

Sacred 3 is all mindless brawl, choose 2 skills per level, choose from the weapons you've unlocked for that character with different bonuses like increased crit chance, chance to stun or just outright damage, I'm only level 5 on two characters so haven't unlocked armour upgrades for either yet, got a bunch of weapon spirits, some of which would only be useful to a team (-10% from health orbs for you, +10% for the team)

I admit I pre-ordered off the back of Sacred 2, found out that it was all corridors, didn't cancel my pre-order anyway  and having enough fun rampaging. Difficulty is pretty good on legendary, I'm not storming through the levels now and I'll have to start co op soon as dying in the same spot, near enough

The humour is clearly aimed at kids, the voiceovers from General Aria annoying at best, the writing is poor, only the starting weapon spirit is useful to me so far so can't comment on their voiceovers, but expect them to be as bad as the rest.
Even the main characters sound stupid but, as far as mindless rampage games go, this one seems ok.

It's not worth anything like full price though, £10-15 at best

reviewText:
Despite all the bad reactions this game has been getting, I'm going to try and give this my honest opinion.

First off, the game is called sacred 3. That name is all wrong, the only thing it has in common with sacred 1 and 2 is the universe it plays in. Sacred 1 and 2 were giant games, with a huge open world and lots and lots of loot.
This game has none of that.
It's a pretty standard isometric top down view brawler in a fantasy setting. But does that make this game a bad game?
Well if you bought it expecting the same kind of content as part 1 and 2 had, then you most likely will not like this game.
However, if (like me) you've read the gaing news and previews and reviews about this game, you could have known exactly what it was. And im gonna say that, if you accept this game fro what it is. It's not bad, not at all. And actually very fun to play in co-op with some friends.

Is it the same quality as sacred 1 and 2? no, not even close. It should not have been called sacred 3.
But that doesnt mean it is as bad as a lot of people say it is.

reviewText:
I've played it for few hours, didn't explore much of the game, but I managed to experience most of the mechanics.
It isn't your usual hack'n'slash game. I'd say the mechanics are like you would mix these of Sacred and Devil May Cry.
Overhead view mixed with mashing buttons to spam spells. You don't drop equipment like in any of this kind of game. You sometimes receive new weapon for you character after a mission. Also skill/spell gain is totally different. You don't drop skillstones as you would in previous games. You buy skills with gold. About gold, it's pretty much only thing you drop from enemies. Apart from green healing orbs and yellow 'mana' orbs. This is kinda similar to these from God of War games. With gold you upgrade your weapons and skills to have additional effects, so having less skills/equip in general is not that bad as you can 'evolve' them with coins. Combat is really action packed! Much difference comparing to old Sacreds. For me it's even more fast-paced than Diablo 3, but that's just an opinion. Throwing minions into each other or executing them is great.

I'm too lazy to write more, but I might edit this reveiw once I'll play more of the game.

reviewText:
NOTE: This review is writte from a neutral unbiased point of view with the goal to create a review for these who will like the game for what it became.

Alright now let us jump into it.

This game is nothing like the series. It is not an open world RPG with hundreds of different weapons and armors, the number of skills and things you can level up on your own is also limited.

So if you were looking for the old Sacred experience this is the point where you would like to leave.

Now let us get to the part where we talk about what the game is.

* It is hack'n'slay!
* It is kind of like a sidescroller
* It has 100s of mobs swarming around you waiting to be killed
* It is a mission based game

So who would actually enjoy that kind of game? Well if you are the type who both enjoys the Devil May Cry series as well as Diablo then it might be the solid mix between the two that you MIGHT enjoy, especially when playing with friends.

While i do enjoy it so far it is not what i expected but i remain neutral about it. As far as the price goes, if you have a lot of money to spend then sure why wouldn't you wanna buy the game if you are the type of person that would like it? However the game is not worth it's price and it is the only point that makes me sad  about it so far.

It's ok to go in a different way. It is ok to try something new. It is refreshing. In some way.

Now it's up to you to pick a side.

Will you leave having been looking for the old Sacred experience? Or will you appreciate the work that has been put into this game?

I am a gamer and so i say that every game has one aspect or the other that one can enjoy if the game is actually really really bad which Sacred 3 is not.

Edit: Final thoughts:

The game is not what Sacred used to be so the title Sacred 3 is missleading. Just a different project name would have saved the game from a lot of negative reaction. The game itself is not bad... Just overpriced... And different...

And here some TL;DRs"
Player Case 1 (Old Schooler):
You are looking for the old Sacred experience? It is not here. Might as well leave.

Player Case 2 (Open Minded yet a bit poor):
You still DO want the game but you do not have too much money to spend? I suggest waiting until a big sale bring it down by at LEAST 50% then it is worth the price.

Case 3 (Open Minded... With money):
You have the money and you like the direction of the game despite the developers having moved away from what this game is? Take it.

Oh i also appreciate the developers having tried to introduce humor in the dialogues"

As for the price, of course don't pay the full price on steam, get it elsewhere and you can save about half of the price even in the preorder phase. But most games aren't worth the full price Steam starts them out on, I would say $10 - $15 would be a reasonable price for a game such as this.

reviewText:
Much like Dungeon Siege 3, Sacred 3 has little in common with its predecessors besides a name, setting and bright, colourful visuals. It's not so much an 'action RPG' as it is an 'arcade RPG' - more Gauntlet than Diablo. Pick one of four (five via preorder or DLC) pre-made hero/ines and get down to the business of clicking stuff until it dies.

In many ways, Sacred 3 has more in common with the download-only Sacred Citadel than its heavier RPG brothers - it's a button mashing brawler at heart, with linear levels and only as much level-up and customisation option as necessary to give the player some agency. Collectibles are limited to helth, energy and gold - the latter being used to buy upgrades or new skills when you level up.

There's no denying Sacred 3 won't be everyone's cup of tea - it is practically designed for couch co-op with friends and beers, or breezy online play while you and your mates mash buttons and talk trash. It has that quirky European sense of humour that made Sacred 2 surprisingly funny, although tempered by what the developers clearly think an American audience will find funny (and spoiler alert, you probably won't). That said, it has an awkward charm about it that'll either make you snicker, or at least roll your eyes with a smile.

Performance wise, the game runs flawlessly on my machine, the first $50+ game in quite a few months to do so (Wolfenstein, Watch Dogs I am looking at you). The visuals aren't amazing and shouldn't tax most systems, but the art style is big and colourful and mostly pleasing on the eye. Playing on my 46 TV it can be a bit hard to make out what is going on when there's a lot of enemies on the screen
date: but it's usually only a few seconds until everything is dead from one of your combat abilities.\n\nThe music is good and the voice acting is serviceable
recommended: although leaning towards the annoying end of the spectrum. There's a surprising amount of it too

voteText: and each one has its own personality and one-liners. Word to the wise: the default guy you get is super annoying

votesFunny: and it's a departure from its predecessors

reviewText:
The game holds the name Sacred 3 upon itself, but it's a very different game from its predecessors. There is no open world here, there isn't real loot you'll find dropping from your enemies, just gold, health globes and energy globes.

The story seems silly and from the start it's apparent that the game doesn't take itself seriously at all, beginning from the narrator, continuing to what the NPCs say including even your own character and the Souls attached to your weapons.

You play in confined levels that can be pretty short or somewhat long that you pick from a map, after which you get dropped into the level and that you'll navigate until the boss fight at the end, after which you'll leave.

After certain fights (usually Bosses that I've seen) you'll find new Souls for your weapon, as well as new weapons that you'll be able to use (and upgrade if you are high level enough and have enough gold) after completing the mission.

The action is pretty hectic, with enemies attacking in droves while the player has to try and dodge out of the way of powerful attacks, break the shield of bigger enemies to be able to hurt them or stop certain enemies from casting (or interrupt althogether their spell) all the while managing the use of skills that use a limited energy resource.

Personally, I wanted this to be closer to the old games, something more akin to Sacred 2 but, so far, I have been having fun with what this game has to offer. The action can get very busy and even at the normal level of difficulty I found that dying can become rather easy if not paying attention at getting out of the way. Killing the groups of enemies coming at you and emerging victorious is also another fun aspect of the game.

The commands are responsive, the game looks quite nice and performs really well even when downsampling from something like 2880x1620.
I have found a problem with the game crashing whenever I open the friend menu in game but I'm not sure if that's the game or something on my PC.

All in all, the experience with the game so far is really positive. Probably not an experience worth 50€, but I didn't pay that much for it when I preordered, so it's more of a problem for anyone that would want to grab the game now.

reviewText:
Preview in Dutch here:
http://games.♥♥♥.nl/preview/661810/1/1/100/sacred-3.html

Basically a decent 3d beat 'em up-game, but THIS IS NOT AN ARPG!!
Nice graphics, sound etc. See this as Sacred Citadel 2.

Forget about Sacred 1 and Sacred 2. The makers of those games started making Unbended.
Want to enjoy yourself with a nice addictive beat em up? Play THIS!!

***
Korte preview versie:
Sacred 3
Sacred 3 is een 3D beat ‘em up met een RPG-achtig verhaal. Kies een klasse en bevrijd Ancaria van de slechte Zane. De omgevingen waar je dit in doet zijn wisselend en kleurrijk.
Versla massa’s vijanden en bazen. Versterk je moves en wapens. Verken nieuwe gebieden. Ram bekende gebieden opnieuw leeg voor meer goud en xp. En doe dit alles met vrienden: het spel is gemaakt voor vette multiplayeractie.

Waarom gaat dit spel slagen?
Dit belooft een hele degelijke beat ‘em up te worden. Geen van de onderdelen steekt boven de middelmaat uit: goede graphics, leuke soundtrack, geinige gameplay. Het enige wat het goed doet is de verslavingsfactor en laten we eerlijk zijn, een spel heeft niet veel meer nodig. Denk maar aan Minecraft als een recent voorbeeld.

Waar kan het misgaan?
Het spel heet Sacred 3 en vele fans wachten al heel lang op een vervolg dat een hele vette actie-RPG zou moeten worden. Dat is dit zeker niet.
Ook de relatief hoge prijs schrikt nogal af. Als Sacred 3 blijkt heel veel missies en verdieping aan te kunnen brengen in de uiteindelijke versie, dan zal dit veel goed maken.

reviewText:
Sacred 3 promises a third person isometric hack n slash arcade RPG, and it definitely delivers. Sacred 3 brings all of the wit and humour of Sacred Citadel to a faster, more arcade feeling gaming experience with engaging story, interesting characters and completely functional, highly competitive 4 player co-op. Though, the price point may be a little high for the content.

The loot is all but gone from this game, staying true to the arcade feel. Instead you are awarded weapons and weapon upgrades, items, item slots and armor upgrades by completing story and side missions. The weapon and armor upgrades are given to you in a cycle through completing story missions; Weapon 1, Weapon 2, Weapon 3, Armour. Start again with the next four story missions. You progress through these missions through a hub-based world map guided by the Seraphim Aria, and each node on the map can take between 2 and 20 minutes to complete. These range from clearing out a single pathway, surviving 5 waves of enemies to sieging a fortress.  You can visit any node on the map at any time, in any order and however many times you wish, though the final encounter only unlocks after all other story missions have been cleared. A single clear through the map will take you roughly 8 playing hours, 10 for the second. The replayability comes from multiple characters, chasing high scores and playing with your friends.

As you traverse each map node, of which there are 40, the telepathic Seraphim Aria will attempt to guide you. She is only a novice, so don't be too hard on her! She will give you helpful pointers for where to go and roughly what to do, though it is worth mentioning that if you ignore her suggestions, she will harass you until you do it which can become a little bit annoying at times.

The game's difficulty settings ARE actually what they say they are. Knight (Easy) is mindnumbingly easy for a skilled player. You should be in absolutely no danger on this mode, even if you've never played a video game of any kind before. Champion (Medium) is a little more difficult, but nothing short of bosses should give you any trouble. Legend (Hard) is the first difficulty in which health potions should even be needed. You definitely don't want to look away from a fight here! Once you have completed the map on Knight, Champion or Legend, Deity (Impossible) becomes available. Deity increases the suggested level and difficulty of each node on the map, and will be very difficult if attempted without at least one other party member, and it is here that the co-op multiplayer really shines.

The co-op multiplayer is entirely optional, however. Drop in/drop out co-op can be disabled by setting your play session to 'private' if you're more the single player type. You will not be forced to play with any AI companions for doing this either. If you'd rather not have the Online feature at all, Sacred 3 does have an offline mode. Should you choose to partake in the co-op multiplayer, you will be in the same playspace as between 1 and 3 other players. You will work together to clear the map in a strange but kind of fun blend of cooperation and oneupmanship. Exactly how points are awarded is unclear at this point. Simply killing more enemies than your cooperators is not enough to come out with the high score. HOW you kill them matters too. If one of your party members falls in battle, reviving them will also score you some points.

The combat is fast and functional, with new combat arts for each of the four new classes and the returning Seraphim to use, as well as weapon spirits and three weapons each. Each weapon has it's own unique specialty to suit your playstyle. Do you like to keep enemies on their back? Plough through them with brutal force? Dance around the battlefield? It's up to you! Though it is worth nothing that some features/actions are shared between the five classes, so to a certain degree once you have played one it will be very easy to get into another one, and after a while the cycle of dodge and attack starts to feel samey.

Weapon spirits are shards that you collect at random throughout Ancaria, each with it's own personality and modifier for your abilities, ranging from lifesteal, party buffs, shielding, damage reduction, enemy debuffing and more. The spirits have voices, and speak to you as well as your party. This companionship between weapon and wielder adds quite a bit of fun to the game, as the running commentary brings out a lot of laughs. You level them up by finding more shards, boosting their power and thusly, the effect they pass on to you.

Every aspect of your character (with the exception of weapon spirits) are upgradeable using gold found throughout the game. Once you have reached the level requirement to be elligible for the upgrade, you can buy it with gold to boost or change the function of your weapons, armor, combat arts, as well as to buy consumables. There is plenty of gold to be found in the game, so you will usually have more gold than upgrades to spend it on, taking the grind out of the equation.

The enemies vary in strength and skills as the game progresses, though they seem to share some abilities from level 1 and on, only adding either extra abilities or extra effects to make them more dangerous, though there is very little variety in the enemies themselves. Most of the bosses feel bossy, but these can be usually be navigated simply by dodging away when they attack and not standing in the goo. Only a handful of the bosses have any mechanics that make fighting them different from any other. The game does start to feel samey in this regard.

The game has full mouse, keyboard and gamepad support as well as built-in voice communication service. However it is readily apparent that this is a console port as it feels way more natural to play the game with a gamepad. The default keyboard and mouse settings feel somewhat obtuse. Though you are able to map the keyboard and mouse as well as the gamepad to your preference, so with some tweaking the game is very playable with either.

The visuals, special effects, voice acting and optimisation are phenominal. The game is pure beauty, with amazing environments, smooth camera angles and lively and vibrant voice acting.

All told Sacred 3 and it's prequel, Sacred Citadel are GREAT games, and I recommend that any isometric RPG or arcade brawler fan play them. However it is my personal hope that Sacred 4, should there be one, return to the loot-crazed, open worlded and more serious toned Sacred and Sacred 2: Fallen Angel crafted by Ascaron. There are only two jokers in a deck. Deep Silver has played both.


Notable bugs/issues(PC):
-The game is 20GB for no apparent reason.
-The game does not remember your resolution setting from one session to the next
-The game locks up without warning and without reason from time to time
-Crash to desktop
-Sometimes can't equip certain weapons for no apparent reason
-Steam overlay sometimes sticks to the edges of the screen in-game.

reviewText:
http://youtu.be/A14pXgcLWxc

In a nutshell, Sacred 3 is a solid hack and slash game that offers a no nonsense approach that's easy to pick up and play for those who want to hammer away at few attack buttons and little else for several hours. There's no menus to wade through or complexity of character progression which means players who thirst for killing can do so without hindrance.  In this regard the game succeeds, but at the same time does become repetitive quite quickly unless you're well in tune with levelling up your character, or willing to try the others classes to add some variety. As mentioned, if you're a fan of the previous games that afford more depth and exploration, then you're going to probably feel a little let down with what's on offer here as the game is Sacred by name, but certainly not in execution.

Score 7/10 - Review By  Robert Cram
