reviewText:
Sacred 3
Rating: 6/10

First of all this game should not be called Sacred 3. Sacred 1 and 2 were open world games RPG games. Sacred 3 however breaks with the previous iterations and aims for a more console like gameplay. A similar thing happend with Dungeon Siege III. The game is situated in the same world as before, but that is where all comparisons end. Really.

Sacred 3 is a extremely linear, controller-friendly hack-and-slash game, with virtually no RPG elements. It looks pretty, the sound is ok albeit that the comments and voices are very cheesy and becomes annoying soon. Always a lot is happening on the screen so it get's kinda messy sometimes. But that's ok, just hack and hope to survive. With this game and mechanics, you either like it or you don't. I kinda like this game for what it is. Only if you could shut up that woman...

One very, very annoying thing is that it doesn't have a pause function. This is really lame so you have to complete the mission or find a safe spot.

So if you are looking for a open-world, customizations, character-building rpg \ hack-and-slash game, look further. This is definitely nothing for you. If you want to have a nice couch game with scarce dressed women, lots of actions and easy drop-in\drop-out give this a try.

Played it single player.

reviewText:
Nothing like the previous titles, but pretty good nonetheless.

First of all, I'd suggest avoiding the game completely if you don't have a controller. The keyboard and mouse set up is awful.

Secondly, it isn't open world, so if that's your thing, the game will disappoint.

As for the game itself. It's exactly as advertised. An arcade hack 'n' slash. It's fast paced and linear, but pretty fun with 4 players.
You collect gold as you play to pay for any skills/weapons upgrades you want once you reach the minimum level requirement.
There's no real emphasis on depth or builds, meaning that anyone can pick up and play.

Where they went wrong was calling the game Sacred 3. We all wanted Sacred 3 to be an open world/dungeon crawler/adventure rpg and possibly some more Blind Guardian. ;)

Having bought the game £10 cheaper than for sale on Steam and having all the DLC thrown in, I can't complain.
I'd much rather have an open world Sacred, but so far I have been enjoying the game.

Definitely not worth the £40 Steam are looking for. And if open world is your thing, avoid at all costs.

Seems like it'll be a great little time killer, though. If in doubt wait for a sale. :P

reviewText:
The first game ever that made me ask for a refund...

I knew the game wasn't a real Sacred game. I knew the game was just an arcade brawler before buying. I like arcade brawlers, after all.

But this game isn't fun. There's no challenge, the controls are mediocre, and the story... Oh man, that was almost as cringeworthy as the horribly cheesy voice acting. I tried to have fun with it, but couldn't.


This is one of the worst games I've ever played. :(

reviewText:
Being someone who grew up on the Arcade Game Gauntlet, this is much like that.  I can't say if it's like Diablo 3 since I haven't played that.  You have all the typical physics of a Hack n Slash game with coop built in.  So far, I have done ok on my own since I don't play well with others.

Pros: None

Con's: Bad storyline, bad scripting, horrible jokes, and has nothing to do with the first 2 games.

Would not recommend this unless your a huge fan of Gauntlet or classic arcade Hack n Slash

reviewText:
This game is so bad....... If you have played Sacred 1 and 2 and you enjoyed the open world, the loot drops and that you can make your own combo attacks, then you should never ever in your entire life, not for a split second even consider of buying this.....abomination.....of the Sacred series..... The open world isn't there, not even in the slightest form....if you completed a section of a level, a wall of force is created behind you so you must keep going. The only adjustments you can make to your character are so limited that you think: Well this is a waste of time.

I cannot image who in the whole multiverse would ever has the opinion that this game, is a great game. This game is so bad that not even in the alternative version of our world anyone would think this is a great game. I played it for 3 hours to get a good opinion of this game and i regret the day I was thinking: Well maybe I might enjoy this game. I regret the money I used to buy this game, would have prefered to give it to some drug addicts, atleast they would buy drugs and feel happy for a few hours and I regret to have spend 3.3 hours into this game cause I could have hit my head against a brick wall and experience more positive feeling while doing that..........

If you still buy this game now........ Imagine the next situation: Your chained to a bomb. Infront of you is a computer, the main screen of Sacred 3 is shown, next to the computer is a timer and a television screen. As the screen turns on you see the puppet of the Saw series: Hello [insert name]. I want to play a game. You decided to buy Sacred 3 and now you must free yourself from the thoughts of enjoyment given by this game. You as sitting on a bomb which will explode in 6 hours unless you manage to really enjoy this game for atleast 4 hours. Next to the timer is a happiness-meter. If the meter goes into the :-| face it won't count towards the 4 hours of enjoyment. Live or Die. You decide.

You are screwed......... Goodbye

reviewText: Can't pause it (and the menu does come up, it's just not paused--hardy har har), can't save it, can't quit when you want (well you can but you'll have to play it over again), big bright checkpoints aren't actually checkpoints (you'll get to play from much further back than you wanted when you quit and restart) AND the whole thing is on rails so it's not even like you get to wander when you're wandering.  I, umm, respectfully disagree with the game designers about what would be fun to do in a game.

reviewText: To keep it short, this game is bad. Like really really bad. I was huge fan of Sacred 2 but this is just piece of you know what. I don’t even know why do they call it RPG, since it has almost nothing to do with this game genre. No open world, no loot, almost no character development, no NPC dialogues, nothing. You have just linear missions with just one corridor from start to finish, few minibosses on the path and hundreds of mobs that are eager to die. And whole time you have to listen to crappy jokes, probably to make you uninstall this game faster. Some may say that it’s what hack’n’slash games look like but this is poor performance even for them. So unless they give it for free (and even then I would think twice before installing it) don’t bother with buying it, it’s just waste of money and time.

reviewText:
I really loved Sacred Citadel" so I decided to go back and check out the SDacred franchise. I am very glad I did.
Sacred asnd Sacred 2 are considerably deeper than Sacred 3 or Sacred Citadel. All you will find here in Sacred 3 is a very nice looking top down hack and slash. It is very well done and the characters and skill and equiptment management are intuitive and easy to master right out of the box.

The only "issue" I have at this point is that it's kinda tough to find a group....but I don't think the game offers anything that can't be done solo......

It's an older game
date: but it will see play on my machine for awhile...."

reviewText: Unlike most people I haven't played the previous Sacred games, but i do enjoy this one. Varied characters to play with different play styles and skills you can switch out, interesting humor, and hack'n'slash gameplay are the biggest reasons I play. Not only this but it is fun with friends to co-op your way through.\n\nI got this game off of the humble bundle, so it basically wasn't even a dollar for me. If you get it on a sale like that it is completely worth it. If not, I'm not sure I'd pay the full price for it.
